Reminiscences of Hopkins Athletics.
N the last number of the I\Nws-LETTp:R,
mention was made of an article on football. I feel that an apology is due at the
start from one who knows nothing of the
game, whose recollections are therefore
vague. The few data given were kindly
furnished by Prof. Paul Dashiell of the Naval
Academy, who played on the team in '86,
was captain in '87 and '88, and was at the
same time our leader ih baseball and in athletics generally. He is well known to all
football players as expert and umpire. I
had hoped to give some data of the game
in the '90s, but the information requested
has not reached me.
Among the players on Dashiell'a team
and shortly afterwards, were George
Morrison, now a rising lawyer here,
Wyatt Randall, formerly associate in
the University, Stuart Symington, Professor
at Amherst, Horace Burrough, now in business here, the Willoughby brothers, one of
whom is Professor in the University, the
other Treasurer of Porto Rico, Charles
Coates, Professor at Tulane University, and
Charles Herty, Professor at the University
of Georgia.
Hopkins teams were never heavy teams,
the average weight of the men being about
155 lbs. In those days there was no medical
school; the players were undergraduates or
graduate students who were mostly Hopkins
B. A.'s ; they had grown up together and
tried from their Freshman year to make the
team; it was a home combination; hence
there was the same spirit of friendship and
comradeship, the same subordination of individual interest to team interest, which has
in late years been the noticeable characteristic of our lacrosse teams. Our undergraduates are generally light men, hence the difficulty of getting an undergraduate team in
these days when weight is so important.
Formerly heavy teams were not as common,
and we could encounter with hope of success
the players of institutions whose present

I

teams would outclass any undergraduate
team we could get together, as the following
data show.
We played the Naval Academy every year.
They usually won, but in the year '88 (or
'87) we beat them. We played the University of Virginia for the first time in '88;
score 16 to 0 in favor of Hophins. In the
same year we played the University of Pennsylvania; they won by the score of 22 to 12.
The chief features of the game as I recall
it were the crumpling of the Hopkins line
by Penn's giant heavy weight, Wagenhurst,
and the skill of Dashiell and his light team.
The only game with Princeton which Prof.
Dashiell remembers was in '86, Princeton
won; score 104 to 01 Something to remember; we have not played Princeton since,
I think. St. John's was always a rival, and
the games were close. We played Gallaudet, Western Maryland, and, I think, Maryland Agricultural every year.
Of the players in the '90s I chiefly recall
Stuart Janney, who captained the team and
was an all-round athlete, taking the leading
place in his day that Dashiell had held previuosly. Mr. Janney is now practicing law
in Baltimore and is the present alumni delegate to the Athletic Board.
The conditions then were so different from
the present conditions, that a sketch of them
may be novel to most of the readers of the
1\11,vs-LETTER. There was no cage, and practice for games was at Druid Hill Park on
the field now used for lacrosse practice.
Though we had no cage, we had a beautiful
athletic field of our own. Clifton, the country place of Mr. Johns Hopkins, since bought
by the city as Clifton Park, was then owned
by the University. The trustees had drained.
levelled and sodded a large field close to
the Hopkins Mansion. A room in the latter
was fitted up with lockers Its dressing room.
There was no grand stand, but a broad
grassy terrace a few feet higher than the
field and shaded by fine trees served the

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

purpose; settees and chairs from the house
were brought out for those who wished them
but the students and most of the other spectators stood or sat on the grass. Athletics
in this field made a lovely picture; the perfectly levelled field with the uniformed
teams, the bright dresses of the ladies on
the green terrace against the background of
giant pines and cedars, the view bounded on
every side by masses of foliage, nothing dirty
in sight. It was beautiful but there were
drawbacks. We could collect gate-money at
the western entrance to the grounds, but
from the rear anyone could enter, and many
thrifty souls preferred the rear entrance.
Hence gate-moneys were small. Then the
distance from the University! I suppose it
is about the same distance now, but rapid
transit annihilates distance, and this was before the days of rapid transit. horse cars
meandered through Baltimore Street and
found their way out the Harford Road as
far as a brewery; there they stopped, and
there was a quarter-mile of dust or mud to
tramp through to the grounds. The correct
thing was to take a seat in one of the omnibuses hired by the Athletic Association on
speculation—sometimes a losing speculation.
The 'buses lined up on 'Toward Street in
front of the gym. at 2 P. M. The teams
were in the big 'bus in the van, the spectators
following in smaller 'buses; with banners
waving, college yells resounding, the procession slowly rambled out Charles Street,
North Avenue and the Harford Road to the
grounds, taking an hour or more for the
trip. The 'buses were slow, but the students
were not. They enjoyed every dusty moment; friends and strangers were greeted
impartially; the chief rooter was busy; one
could hear him roar "What's the matter
with the girl in the blue dress?" and the
answering chorus "She's all right." The
girls in blue or any other color seemed to
enjoy it—it was a break in the quiet of the
streets—for Baltimore streets were quiet
then; it was before they were made a roaring
pandemonium by the electric cars.
There were no locker-rents then to maintain athletics. The Athletic Association was
a body of students numbering 80 or 90 who
paid $2.00 each per year. The necessary
balance was raised by passing the hat—
among the faculty mostly. It began in the

fall when the football team made the first
touch. Towards Spring there was a generous rivalry between the baseball and lacrosse
teams as to which should get at the faculty
first. It was an old custom in most colleges
that the faculty should have the perennial
privilege of helping the boys out, yet the
team emissaries were not always received
with enthusiasm. There were artists among
them, however, who had a magic touch, chief
of whom was IIerty, a very genial man; it
was believed that no one could resist his
blandishments; some of his friends were so
impressed with his ability in this line, that
they declared the University missed the
chance of its life in not electing him President.
Our finances were on a precarious footing
at best. Yet we ran the teams. The players
helped by paying their own petty expenses,
often buying their own uniforms. Expenses
were far below the present standard; paid
coaches, trainers and rubbers were unknown.
Old players coached without pay. Jim, the
gymnasium janitor, was rubber, students assisting if needed.
The spirit of self help and mutual help in
those days was admirable. The weak point
in the situation was the begging for funds,
which was unavoidable. This came to an
end when the new gymnasium and the cage
were built with considerable cost to the
University at a time when the University was
suffering from a depreciation in value of investments. It is the custom in many of the
larger colleges to charge a gymnasium lockerrent, which pays or helps to pay the expenses
of the gymnasium; the University authorities
decided to adopt this plan in the new gymnasium, but the student body requested that
the locker-rents should be given to the Athletic Association to defray the expense for
the athletics, promising that no further assistance should be asked of the faculty or
alumni. The Board of Trustees granted this
request. The directors of the Athletic Association know about what sum they can
count on in a given year, and have never exceeded it.
In closing, I wish to add a few words on
what appear to an older man dangers in the
athletic system of the present day. I am
not referring to Hopkins conditions, which
for obvious reasons are exceptional, but to

THE NEWS-LETTER.
the conditions prevailing in many large colleges.
An idea seems to be gaining ground among
American students that a man who plays
on a team gives something to his fellow students which it is their duty to pay for; that
he not only should receive reward in athletic
honors, in medals or in costly trophies, but
should have his personal expenses paid in
greater or less degree, still feeling magnanimous in that he has "given" his time. Is
this a sportsmanlike spirit? It introduces
the idea of payment for service rendered;
is it not rather a step in the direction of the
spirit of the hired gladiator? The teams of the
great. athletic colleges with their enormous
revenues and lavish expenditure have set a
standard which has affected every college
in the country, and which seems to me a
menace to a healthy athletic spirit. Men
now are doubtless better trained, but I regret
the old simple days when college athletics
were less business and more sport.
Another danger is the advent of students
whose chief or only interest in college is athletics. I gave the present standing of the
old football players whom I remember, with
a purpose. I wished to show you that they
had become men of mark. Everyone of these
men ranked high as scholars, some exceptionally high. They were fine athletes because
they were men who would not undertake
a thing unless they could do it well. Athletics to them was sport for leisure hours,
not a thing foremost in their minds.
It is a good trait of our people to strive
to attain the highest excellence in whatever
they undertake, but students should remember that colleges, if they fulfil their purpose,
prepare them for their life-work. Few wish
to make athletics their life-work, many find
it a pleasant mode of frittering away three
or four years of their life.

THE FIRST FEED OF THE
HULLABALOO CLUB.
The Hullabaloo Club of the Johns Hopkins
University was founded in 1903 by the members of that year's Senior Class. Its object,
as set forth by its founders, was to promote
good fellow-ship among the members of the
Senior class. .In the two years of the existence of the organization, it has ably fulfilled
the purpose of its founders, and in its
"feeds" there has been shown an enthusiasm
and class spirit which has not often had a
chance to show itself elsewhere. Last year
the Club held a series of field nights which
proved very popular, and attracted almost
the whole Senior class. This year the Board
of Governors has planned to have a smoker
and "feed" on the first Friday of each
month, the subscription for each being 50
cents. The Johns Hopkins Club has given
permission to the Board to use its rooms
for the celebrations, and, for the present at
least, they will be held there.
The Club will hold its first "feed" in the
Johns IIopkins Club's rooms on Friday, November 4th.
The ceremonies will begin
at 8.30. Every effort has been made to
make the evening a success, and it is expected that every member of the Senior class
will be present. Everyone certainly ought
to turn out on occasions like this. There is
no better way of getting really to know the
members of one's class, and besides, the
bigger the crowd, the faster and "furiouser"
the fun will be, the greater the enthusiasm
and noise, and the better the general good
time all round. And after all, when you
come to think of it, such occasions are almost the only times when our classes can
get together and see something of the fascination of that careless atmosphere of smoke
and song which forms part of what is called,
in other Universities, college life. When our
classes do have a chance to get together, no
one can afford to be absent from the gathering. The Hullabaloo Board is going to make
such chances more frequent in future, and
if the present feed is successful, the first
of each month will see another of the same
kind.
So far as providing the actual "feed" for
Friday night goes, the Committee has done
everything to supply enough for all, and a
variety of everything. There will be all

THE NEWS-LETTER.

5
—

• The prospects for the Mandolin Club are
very promising. A number of candidates
have come forward, so that, with the old
men, the Club will consist of about thirty.
Of the candidates, however, only two are
Freshmen. This is a poor showing, especially when one considers that next year and
the year after they will have to help make
up the Club. So far, only one man has
offered to play the guitar. This is unfortunate, as it forces both Mandolin and Banjo
Clubs to depend on men who have left the
University, and who are unable, consequently, to come to rehearsals.
The Banjo Club, under Mr. Marshall, who
led it several years ago, should be very good.
As in former years, it has started out badly,
but it will probably improve a great deal as
soon as more banjos and guitars can be
found.
So much for the Clubs, now for the trips.
Two long trips are taken each year. This
year they will probably be to the Eastern
Shore and to northern and eastern Virginia,
although it has not been decided yet which
will be taken at Christmas and which at
Easter. Another trip is the one to National
Park Seminary. This is so popular that a
great many men come to practice just to be
able to go on it. Then there is the Hannah
More trip. On this the men always have
an enjoyable evening with the girls, and
come home with trophies of various kinds,
such as handkerchiefs, etc. The Catonsville
trip is popular, too. Besides these there are
a number of other concerts where the men
have a little recreation singing "The Little
Old Red Shawl," "I've Been Working On
The Railroad," "Mona," etc., and where
Mr. Bristol brings the house down with his
"0-0-0-oo-O'Brien" and the story about the
man who fell to the ground "peachless."
Altogether the men pass a very pleasant year
and are sorry when it is over.

W. WATURS PAGON.

UNDERGRADUATE NOTES.
The Freshman class has elected the following permanent officers:—
President—G. Pitts Raleigh.
Vice-President—W ii. Iglehart.
Secretary—Albert Grauer.
- Treasurer—George A Stewart.
Historian—M. S. Caples.
Sergeant at Arms—L. W. Pierce.
The Senate has been organized by the
Senior class. The election resulted as follows:—
President—Francis Morris Miller.
Clerk—J. Earle Mifflin.
Sergeant at Arms—H. V. Morse.
The Chess Club will re-organize this week
for the work of the year. The Club expects
to arrange some good matches with other
organizations ,and the indications are that
something will be doing this year in the
"sport of kings." Here's success to the
Chess Club!

EDITORIAL.
Some comment has been heard upon the
small but very select number of students
present at the football game with St. Mary's
two weeks ago. Some students expressed
the feeling that fifty cents was too much to
pay to see a game with such a team as St.
Mary's.
Not long ago, in talking with a prominent
member of the Athletic Board who opposed
having baseball and football teams under
the present conditions, he expressed the following opinion in support of his view: "The
undergraduate body at Hopkins has the
worst reputation of any such body in this
country when it comes to going to games
and to 'rooting' the teams on to victory."
Not having definite information on the
subject, this statement could not be refuted.
And yet the NEWS-LETTER believes that, after
all, part of this fault lies with the management of the teams. What the NEWS-LETTER
means is this: we believe that fifty cents is
a price which keeps many students away who
would otherwise be glad to go to the majority of the games. Making the price, say
twenty-five cents for students only, we think,
would be money in the hands of the
management. If there was a large and enthusiastic body of students at each game to
"whoop things up" so to speak, there would

undoubtedly be a larger crowd of outsiders
present, for the simple reason that if the
students themselves are enthusiastic over
their teams, others will also take a more
lively interest in Hopkins.
In suggesting the advisability of the various athletic teams of the University making
special rates of admission to games for students, we believe we are simply voicing a
feeling that has long been felt if not expressed. We are convinced that not only
would such a procedure be a great relief to
loyal supporters of the teams, but would
also be a source of increased revenue to the
Athletic Association.
Of course this is all conjecture as to the
final results. But judging from the results
at other colleges, which have special rates
for students, the same plan should be successful here. The plan of offering season tickets
at a reduced rate last spring was a step in
the right direction, but it was not enough.
Few students will buy a season ticket. On
the other hand the NEWS-LETTER thinks most
students would go if the price were twentyfive cents. At any rate the NEWS-LETTER
offers this as a suggestion to the management
with the hope that it will be tried several
times to see whether it is a successful or an
unsuccessful plan.
In a letter to the "News" last week, Mr.
Richard H. Pleasants, of the Baltimore bar,
made the suggestion that the city should
purchase the present buildings of the University for the use of its various free schools.
He gave several reasons for thinking that
such an action would be desirable, among
which were the following:
It would give the University the nucleus
of a fund for the erection of new buildings
on our grounds at IIomewood.
It would provide homes for the Polytechnic Institute, the Maryland Institute and a
finely located public hall for educational
gatherings.
Mr. Keyser, President of the Board of
Trustees of the University, said when told of
Mr. Pleasant's suggestion, that the University was not trying to sell its buildings at
the present time, but that if the city should
renew the offer at any future time when the
University was about to move to Homewood,
it would certainly be favorably considered.

1

7

THE NEWS-LETTER.
The group of buildings would naturally be
best adapted for educational purposes and
would be what is needed for the use of the
Maryland and of the Polytechnic Institutes.
President Remsen confirmed what Mr.
Keyser said on the subject, and there seems
to be little chance that the subject will come
up again until the University is moving to
the country, when such a disposition of the
buildings would probably be advantageous
to both sides. The sale of the six buildings
should bring the University quite a large
amount, which would probably come in very
useful for the erection of new buildings at
Homewood.
To the NEWS-LETTER:
Not for a number of years has such lively
interest been evidenced at Hopkins as is
today in athletic sports. There is a general
feeling among the students that Hopkins
must be represented not only on the lacrosse
field, but on the gridiron, the oval and the
diamond, too. When the football team was
recognized a few weeks ago it was a step in
the right direction; but it was only brought
about by the students insisting that the members of the Athletic Board, as their representative, take this action. These same men
are DOW clamoring for a baseball team, saying that if the "prep" schools and small
colleges can be represented by teams playing
the national game, what, then, is the matter
with Hopkins? This early in the year we
are told, and by men who ,know, that there
are over 25 men, the majority of whom
have been stars in other University teams,
and who are ready and anxious to represent
Hopkins on the diamond next Spring. These
men have pledged themselves to play, the
students want a team, and the Ahtletic Association, as the representative body of the
students, should act promptly. If the Athletic Association carries out the will of the
student body, the University will have a
baseball team next Spring.

HOPKINS, 0; U. M., 0.
Backed by about twenty-five or thirty enthusiastic rooters, the 'Varsity foottball team
went to Westminster, Saturday, October 29,
and played a peculiarly interesting game
with Western Maryland College. Despite
the rocky and undulating cornfield on which
the game was played, and which bore no
trace of ever having been marked off, our
men put up a creditable showing. The team
arrived at Westminster about noon, and at
2.30 started down the half-mile cow-path,
which led from the dressing room to the
field. Western Maryland won the kick-off,
and sent the pigskin through a number of
erratic evolutions for the distance of about
ten feet. Hopkins fumbled on the catch and
the ball went to Western Maryland for the
first down. Hopkins held them for downs
and recovered the ball.
About this time the much talked of Roberts, Western Maryland's fullback, received
the greater part of Blanck's knee in the
regions of his dinner. The Western
Maryland rooters began to grow restless and despite the noble efforts of their
leader (whose voice, by the way, was only
harmonious when quiet), their songs lapsed
into a nursery whine of dissatisfaction. This
whine increased as the game proceeded. It
was almost impossible for the referee to
judge downs on the unmarked field. Consequently it was necessary for the line-keepers
to carry the line across the field at every
down, to satisfy our opponents that they
were not being cheated. At the Western
Maryland fifteen-yard line, Blanck, who was
taking the ball around left-end for a touchdown, severely wrenched his ankle on one of
the many small bowlders which were inter-

spersed with the corn stubble, and in falling

Western Maryland worked the ball up to

mathematical abilities of umpire and referee
to settle. The faint line, which before the

goal posts and it was evidently the intention

kick-off should be from that point, when a
compromise was arranged. It was found
that, with a few irregularities the field sloped
from either end, down to a miniature gorge.

Hopkins held them for two downs, and end
play was tried by Western Maryland. This
succeeded to the point of losing the ball.

the humoring of spoiled children, he refused

field and wanted to fight Blanek. The latter
was accommodating and the half-back woke
up some ten feet away. The field then
swarmed with the rooters of both teams and
for a few moments things were lively. The

Y. M. C. A. MAIL.
Oh, it's every day I wander,
To the basement down below,
Where the pigeon holes are many
In the J. H. U. P. 0.;
Oh, it's every day I wander,
But forever and for aye,
Come my only, only letters,
From the Y. (why?) M. C. A.
Many cordial invitations,
Do these kindly missives bear.
Such as "Come and be a member,
Join with us in evening prayer;"
Or "A Bible class is forming
Under Mr. So and So,
You'll perform an act of kindness,
If you would but try and go."
And they've other invitations,
Formal bids to formal lunch,
(Tis too bad that at these functions
They debar all Roman punch).
Large receptions in the evening,
"Evening dress is not the style,"
And St. Andrew chapter meetings;
"Just drop in a little while."

Though these bids are very many,
Which I get from day to day,
Four, or five, or six, or seven,
From the Y. (why?) M. C. A.;
Yet another kind of bidding,
Coming first in ones and twos,
Then increasing to the hundreds,
"You will please to pay your dues."
Sometimes think I that these people
Are not financiers a bit,
Spending fortunes out on paper,
Getting nothing back from it.
But of course there are some members,
One, or two, or mayhap, three,
Who do pay with great devotion,
(Oftimes one year out of three).
Surely bills would try a mortal
Much more saintly than am I,
When they teem by tens of hundreds,
While I stand defenseless by;
Think you, I should view them calmly?
Bills are bills, some people say,
True, with but one lone exception,
That's the Y. (why?. M. C. A.
First, I used to like attention
From the Y. (why?) M. C. A.,
Now I do grow tired and tireder,
Tired and more tired every day;
For the way my box is crowded
From the bottom to the top,
Makes me ask the fatal question,
Y. M. C. A won't you stop?
Oh, it's every day I wander,
To the basement down below,
Where the pigeon holes are many
In the J. H. U. P. 0.;
Oh, it's every day I wander,
But forever and for aye,
Come my only, only letters,
From the Y.(why?) M. C. A.

The lady he loved best,
And by her house at evening,
When the sun had gone to rest,
He warbled until daylight
And would have warbled more,
But morning light disclosed a sign
"To Let" upon the door.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
PROGRESS IN THE ORIENTAL
SEMINARY.
The work of the Oriental Seminary has
opened up this year most auspiciously.
About a dozen new students have taken up
work in the Seminary viz., Mr. J. R. Gaar
of Dodson, La., A. B. of Westminster (Texas), College, 1901; Mr. 0. J. H. Preus of Decorah, Ia., A. B. of Luther College, 1901;
Mr. Applestein, Mr. Bernstein, Mr. Bransky,
Mr. Bloudheim, Mr. Potz, Mr. Ellison, Mr.
Edlavitch, Mr. Parelhoff, Mr. Pleet, etc.
The impression is rapidly gaining more
and more ground that ancient history in the
light of the important discoveries made in
Western Asia and Egypt can be treated
authoritatively only by an Orientalist, and
therefore the number of historical students
who avail themselves of Professor Johnston's course on the history of the Ancient
East shows a gratifying increase.
In accordance with its policy of not repeating certain definite courses in rotation
in a cycle of three or four years, as other
departments do, a number of entirely new
courses has been begun in the Oriental Seminary. Professor Haupt interprets this year
the Books of Ruth, Lamentations, and Esther
in the Old Testament Seminary. Professor
Johnston is giving n new course on the
famous Babylonian Code of IIammurabi with
special reference to the corresponding legal
sections of the Old Testament. Dr. Blake,
in addition to his courses in Tagalog, the
principal dialect spoken in the Philippine
Islands, has for the first time begun a course
in Ilokan. Another innovation in the Seminary is Dr. Ember's course in Hebrew conversation, in which the German, Russian and
Polish method of pronunciation is used. As
90 per cent. of Jews at the present time use
this so-called Ashkenazic pronunciation, this
course is important for practical purposes.
Mr. Dennis, who spent last winter with
Dr. Reissner assisting in and directing certain archeological excavations in Egypt, has
returned to the University and will resume
his work in Egyptology under the direction
of Professor Johnston.
Professor Haupt has just published his
new metrical translation of Ecclesiastes.
This translation was read by the author at
the second International Congress for the
History of Religions, held this summer at

11

Basle, and attracted a great deal of attention.
The book is dedicated to President D. C.
Gilman of the Carnegie Institute, whom the
author calls the creator of the First American University.

LOCKE: THE MAN AND HIS WORK.
The programme for the two hundredth
anniversary of the death of the philosopher,
John Locke, which was held in McCoy
Hall, Johns Hopkins University, on Tuesday,
November 1, at 5 P. M., was as follows:
"Locke's Philosophy and Psychology,"
Principal C. Lloyd Morgan of Bristol, England, and Prof. F. J. E. Woodbridge, of
Columbia University.
"Locke as a Physician," Dr. William Osier
of the Johns Hopkins Medical School.
"Locke on Toleration," Prof. J. McBride
Sterrett of George Washington University.
"Locke's Political and Social Views," Dr.
William T. Harris, United States Commissioner of Education.
Professor J. Mark Baldwin, director of the
department of psychology at Johns Hopkins,
will make a brief introductory address as
the presiding officer at the celebration.

MRS. FRANKLIN LECTURES.
Mrs. Christine Ladd Franklin delivered
this week before the Psychological Seminary
of the Johns Hopkins University, her lecture
upon "The New Concept of the Infinite,"
which she recently presented in St. Louis
before the Congress of Arts and Sciences.
The latter part of November Mrs. Franklin
will begin in the department of philosophy
and psychology of the University a course
of lectures in logic and vision. Mrs. Franklin is a fellow of the University.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

NOTES FROM OTHER COLLEGES.
Dr. Dudley Allen Sargent, the well-known
director of Harvard's Hemenway Gymnasium, has just published an authoritative
treatise on Physical Culture under the title
of "Health, Strength and Power."
In this work of 280 pages, Dr. Sargent
has aimed to make physical training more
popular by devising a series of exercises
which require no apparatus whatever. It
is profusely illustrated with half-tone illustrations from original photographs furnished
by the author. At this time, when the benefits of outdoor living and breathing pure
air are being agitated, the simple exercsies,
when followed as here described, cannot but
be found beneficial to the highest degree.
The corporation committee on the retirement of professors has proposed a plan
whereby professors over seventy years of
age who have been with Brown University
twenty yeras or more shall be retired. The
details are not ready for publication, as the
plan must be submitted to the faculty, but
it may be said that the scheme is practically
the same as that in vogue at Yale and other
institutions.
The subject of dress reform is to the fore
at Princeton this year. It has been a fad
with the undergraduate of late years to appear in the class room in the garb of a stone
breaker, and of an impecunious stone breaker at that. Now certain upper-class men
have decided that this habit is injurious to
the reputation of the university and have
undertaken its reform with a fair prospect of
success. Flannel shirts, overalls, brimless
hats have been tabooed and even the sweater
has fallen under the ban.
The latest West Point toast to the ladies
is:
Our arms your defense,
Your arms our recompense—
Fall in!
The rooters in leading eastern universities
are very chary of giving the cheer for individual players on the football field. When

it is given it means something and is one
of the greatest honors that can be accorded
a player. Oftentimes when a man makes
a long gain the one who made the run possible deserves the cheer. Nice discriminations, then, must be made, and when three
cheers are given a man he knows he really
deserved the ovation.
The following are a few of the summaries
of the report of Professor Edwin G. Dexter
of the University of Illinois, who has been
conducting an extensive investigation of injuries received in college football.
1. About one college man in ten the
country over plays football.
2. About twice as large a proportion of
the men in the small colleges play the game
as in the larger universities.
3. About one player in thirty-five is injured sufficiently each season to necessitate
loss of time from college duties.
4. The opinion of college officers regarding the value of the game is about 17 to 1
in its favor.
These results are based on statistics furnished by the officers of sixty of the more
important colleges of the country. The figures cover the last ten years, during which
period of time, out of the number of 22,766
students playing the game 654 were injured
to such a degree that they lost time from
their classes. This is in the proportion of
less than 3 to every 100 players. Of the
serious injuries but eight were of a permanent nature. Three cases resulted fatally;
two of these were untrained men.
President Guy P. Benton, of Miami University, has expressed the following strong
opposition to football:
"I recognise the fact that one college could
not act alone. It would be dubbed a 'sissy'
institution. I should like to see the presidents of all colleges get together to abolish
football.
"I favor athletics, and want boys to have
a good time, but football is too hazardous
to be a justifiable college sport."
Several Miami football players were hurt
in a game at Columbus recently.

Reminiscences of Hopkins Athletics.
N the last number of the I\Nws-LETTp:R,
mention was made of an article on football. I feel that an apology is due at the
start from one who knows nothing of the
game, whose recollections are therefore
vague. The few data given were kindly
furnished by Prof. Paul Dashiell of the Naval
Academy, who played on the team in '86,
was captain in '87 and '88, and was at the
same time our leader ih baseball and in athletics generally. He is well known to all
football players as expert and umpire. I
had hoped to give some data of the game
in the '90s, but the information requested
has not reached me.
Among the players on Dashiell'a team
and shortly afterwards, were George
Morrison, now a rising lawyer here,
Wyatt Randall, formerly associate in
the University, Stuart Symington, Professor
at Amherst, Horace Burrough, now in business here, the Willoughby brothers, one of
whom is Professor in the University, the
other Treasurer of Porto Rico, Charles
Coates, Professor at Tulane University, and
Charles Herty, Professor at the University
of Georgia.
Hopkins teams were never heavy teams,
the average weight of the men being about
155 lbs. In those days there was no medical
school; the players were undergraduates or
graduate students who were mostly Hopkins
B. A.'s ; they had grown up together and
tried from their Freshman year to make the
team; it was a home combination; hence
there was the same spirit of friendship and
comradeship, the same subordination of individual interest to team interest, which has
in late years been the noticeable characteristic of our lacrosse teams. Our undergraduates are generally light men, hence the difficulty of getting an undergraduate team in
these days when weight is so important.
Formerly heavy teams were not as common,
and we could encounter with hope of success
the players of institutions whose present

I

teams would outclass any undergraduate
team we could get together, as the following
data show.
We played the Naval Academy every year.
They usually won, but in the year '88 (or
'87) we beat them. We played the University of Virginia for the first time in '88;
score 16 to 0 in favor of Hophins. In the
same year we played the University of Pennsylvania; they won by the score of 22 to 12.
The chief features of the game as I recall
it were the crumpling of the Hopkins line
by Penn's giant heavy weight, Wagenhurst,
and the skill of Dashiell and his light team.
The only game with Princeton which Prof.
Dashiell remembers was in '86, Princeton
won; score 104 to 01 Something to remember; we have not played Princeton since,
I think. St. John's was always a rival, and
the games were close. We played Gallaudet, Western Maryland, and, I think, Maryland Agricultural every year.
Of the players in the '90s I chiefly recall
Stuart Janney, who captained the team and
was an all-round athlete, taking the leading
place in his day that Dashiell had held previuosly. Mr. Janney is now practicing law
in Baltimore and is the present alumni delegate to the Athletic Board.
The conditions then were so different from
the present conditions, that a sketch of them
may be novel to most of the readers of the
1\11,vs-LETTER. There was no cage, and practice for games was at Druid Hill Park on
the field now used for lacrosse practice.
Though we had no cage, we had a beautiful
athletic field of our own. Clifton, the country place of Mr. Johns Hopkins, since bought
by the city as Clifton Park, was then owned
by the University. The trustees had drained.
levelled and sodded a large field close to
the Hopkins Mansion. A room in the latter
was fitted up with lockers Its dressing room.
There was no grand stand, but a broad
grassy terrace a few feet higher than the
field and shaded by fine trees served the

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

purpose; settees and chairs from the house
were brought out for those who wished them
but the students and most of the other spectators stood or sat on the grass. Athletics
in this field made a lovely picture; the perfectly levelled field with the uniformed
teams, the bright dresses of the ladies on
the green terrace against the background of
giant pines and cedars, the view bounded on
every side by masses of foliage, nothing dirty
in sight. It was beautiful but there were
drawbacks. We could collect gate-money at
the western entrance to the grounds, but
from the rear anyone could enter, and many
thrifty souls preferred the rear entrance.
Hence gate-moneys were small. Then the
distance from the University! I suppose it
is about the same distance now, but rapid
transit annihilates distance, and this was before the days of rapid transit. horse cars
meandered through Baltimore Street and
found their way out the Harford Road as
far as a brewery; there they stopped, and
there was a quarter-mile of dust or mud to
tramp through to the grounds. The correct
thing was to take a seat in one of the omnibuses hired by the Athletic Association on
speculation—sometimes a losing speculation.
The 'buses lined up on 'Toward Street in
front of the gym. at 2 P. M. The teams
were in the big 'bus in the van, the spectators
following in smaller 'buses; with banners
waving, college yells resounding, the procession slowly rambled out Charles Street,
North Avenue and the Harford Road to the
grounds, taking an hour or more for the
trip. The 'buses were slow, but the students
were not. They enjoyed every dusty moment; friends and strangers were greeted
impartially; the chief rooter was busy; one
could hear him roar "What's the matter
with the girl in the blue dress?" and the
answering chorus "She's all right." The
girls in blue or any other color seemed to
enjoy it—it was a break in the quiet of the
streets—for Baltimore streets were quiet
then; it was before they were made a roaring
pandemonium by the electric cars.
There were no locker-rents then to maintain athletics. The Athletic Association was
a body of students numbering 80 or 90 who
paid $2.00 each per year. The necessary
balance was raised by passing the hat—
among the faculty mostly. It began in the

fall when the football team made the first
touch. Towards Spring there was a generous rivalry between the baseball and lacrosse
teams as to which should get at the faculty
first. It was an old custom in most colleges
that the faculty should have the perennial
privilege of helping the boys out, yet the
team emissaries were not always received
with enthusiasm. There were artists among
them, however, who had a magic touch, chief
of whom was IIerty, a very genial man; it
was believed that no one could resist his
blandishments; some of his friends were so
impressed with his ability in this line, that
they declared the University missed the
chance of its life in not electing him President.
Our finances were on a precarious footing
at best. Yet we ran the teams. The players
helped by paying their own petty expenses,
often buying their own uniforms. Expenses
were far below the present standard; paid
coaches, trainers and rubbers were unknown.
Old players coached without pay. Jim, the
gymnasium janitor, was rubber, students assisting if needed.
The spirit of self help and mutual help in
those days was admirable. The weak point
in the situation was the begging for funds,
which was unavoidable. This came to an
end when the new gymnasium and the cage
were built with considerable cost to the
University at a time when the University was
suffering from a depreciation in value of investments. It is the custom in many of the
larger colleges to charge a gymnasium lockerrent, which pays or helps to pay the expenses
of the gymnasium; the University authorities
decided to adopt this plan in the new gymnasium, but the student body requested that
the locker-rents should be given to the Athletic Association to defray the expense for
the athletics, promising that no further assistance should be asked of the faculty or
alumni. The Board of Trustees granted this
request. The directors of the Athletic Association know about what sum they can
count on in a given year, and have never exceeded it.
In closing, I wish to add a few words on
what appear to an older man dangers in the
athletic system of the present day. I am
not referring to Hopkins conditions, which
for obvious reasons are exceptional, but to

THE NEWS-LETTER.
the conditions prevailing in many large colleges.
An idea seems to be gaining ground among
American students that a man who plays
on a team gives something to his fellow students which it is their duty to pay for; that
he not only should receive reward in athletic
honors, in medals or in costly trophies, but
should have his personal expenses paid in
greater or less degree, still feeling magnanimous in that he has "given" his time. Is
this a sportsmanlike spirit? It introduces
the idea of payment for service rendered;
is it not rather a step in the direction of the
spirit of the hired gladiator? The teams of the
great. athletic colleges with their enormous
revenues and lavish expenditure have set a
standard which has affected every college
in the country, and which seems to me a
menace to a healthy athletic spirit. Men
now are doubtless better trained, but I regret
the old simple days when college athletics
were less business and more sport.
Another danger is the advent of students
whose chief or only interest in college is athletics. I gave the present standing of the
old football players whom I remember, with
a purpose. I wished to show you that they
had become men of mark. Everyone of these
men ranked high as scholars, some exceptionally high. They were fine athletes because
they were men who would not undertake
a thing unless they could do it well. Athletics to them was sport for leisure hours,
not a thing foremost in their minds.
It is a good trait of our people to strive
to attain the highest excellence in whatever
they undertake, but students should remember that colleges, if they fulfil their purpose,
prepare them for their life-work. Few wish
to make athletics their life-work, many find
it a pleasant mode of frittering away three
or four years of their life.

THE FIRST FEED OF THE
HULLABALOO CLUB.
The Hullabaloo Club of the Johns Hopkins
University was founded in 1903 by the members of that year's Senior Class. Its object,
as set forth by its founders, was to promote
good fellow-ship among the members of the
Senior class. .In the two years of the existence of the organization, it has ably fulfilled
the purpose of its founders, and in its
"feeds" there has been shown an enthusiasm
and class spirit which has not often had a
chance to show itself elsewhere. Last year
the Club held a series of field nights which
proved very popular, and attracted almost
the whole Senior class. This year the Board
of Governors has planned to have a smoker
and "feed" on the first Friday of each
month, the subscription for each being 50
cents. The Johns Hopkins Club has given
permission to the Board to use its rooms
for the celebrations, and, for the present at
least, they will be held there.
The Club will hold its first "feed" in the
Johns IIopkins Club's rooms on Friday, November 4th.
The ceremonies will begin
at 8.30. Every effort has been made to
make the evening a success, and it is expected that every member of the Senior class
will be present. Everyone certainly ought
to turn out on occasions like this. There is
no better way of getting really to know the
members of one's class, and besides, the
bigger the crowd, the faster and "furiouser"
the fun will be, the greater the enthusiasm
and noise, and the better the general good
time all round. And after all, when you
come to think of it, such occasions are almost the only times when our classes can
get together and see something of the fascination of that careless atmosphere of smoke
and song which forms part of what is called,
in other Universities, college life. When our
classes do have a chance to get together, no
one can afford to be absent from the gathering. The Hullabaloo Board is going to make
such chances more frequent in future, and
if the present feed is successful, the first
of each month will see another of the same
kind.
So far as providing the actual "feed" for
Friday night goes, the Committee has done
everything to supply enough for all, and a
variety of everything. There will be all

—

• The prospects for the Mandolin Club are
very promising. A number of candidates
have come forward, so that, with the old
men, the Club will consist of about thirty.
Of the candidates, however, only two are
Freshmen. This is a poor showing, especially when one considers that next year and
the year after they will have to help make
up the Club. So far, only one man has
offered to play the guitar. This is unfortunate, as it forces both Mandolin and Banjo
Clubs to depend on men who have left the
University, and who are unable, consequently, to come to rehearsals.
The Banjo Club, under Mr. Marshall, who
led it several years ago, should be very good.
As in former years, it has started out badly,
but it will probably improve a great deal as
soon as more banjos and guitars can be
found.
So much for the Clubs, now for the trips.
Two long trips are taken each year. This
year they will probably be to the Eastern
Shore and to northern and eastern Virginia,
although it has not been decided yet which
will be taken at Christmas and which at
Easter. Another trip is the one to National
Park Seminary. This is so popular that a
great many men come to practice just to be
able to go on it. Then there is the Hannah
More trip. On this the men always have
an enjoyable evening with the girls, and
come home with trophies of various kinds,
such as handkerchiefs, etc. The Catonsville
trip is popular, too. Besides these there are
a number of other concerts where the men
have a little recreation singing "The Little
Old Red Shawl," "I've Been Working On
The Railroad," "Mona," etc., and where
Mr. Bristol brings the house down with his
"0-0-0-oo-O'Brien" and the story about the
man who fell to the ground "peachless."
Altogether the men pass a very pleasant year
and are sorry when it is over.

EDITORIAL.
Some comment has been heard upon the
small but very select number of students
present at the football game with St. Mary's
two weeks ago. Some students expressed
the feeling that fifty cents was too much to
pay to see a game with such a team as St.
Mary's.
Not long ago, in talking with a prominent
member of the Athletic Board who opposed
having baseball and football teams under
the present conditions, he expressed the following opinion in support of his view: "The
undergraduate body at Hopkins has the
worst reputation of any such body in this
country when it comes to going to games
and to 'rooting' the teams on to victory."
Not having definite information on the
subject, this statement could not be refuted.
And yet the NEWS-LETTER believes that, after
all, part of this fault lies with the management of the teams. What the NEWS-LETTER
means is this: we believe that fifty cents is
a price which keeps many students away who
would otherwise be glad to go to the majority of the games. Making the price, say
twenty-five cents for students only, we think,
would be money in the hands of the
management. If there was a large and enthusiastic body of students at each game to
"whoop things up" so to speak, there would

undoubtedly be a larger crowd of outsiders
present, for the simple reason that if the
students themselves are enthusiastic over
their teams, others will also take a more
lively interest in Hopkins.
In suggesting the advisability of the various athletic teams of the University making
special rates of admission to games for students, we believe we are simply voicing a
feeling that has long been felt if not expressed. We are convinced that not only
would such a procedure be a great relief to
loyal supporters of the teams, but would
also be a source of increased revenue to the
Athletic Association.
Of course this is all conjecture as to the
final results. But judging from the results
at other colleges, which have special rates
for students, the same plan should be successful here. The plan of offering season tickets
at a reduced rate last spring was a step in
the right direction, but it was not enough.
Few students will buy a season ticket. On
the other hand the NEWS-LETTER thinks most
students would go if the price were twentyfive cents. At any rate the NEWS-LETTER
offers this as a suggestion to the management
with the hope that it will be tried several
times to see whether it is a successful or an
unsuccessful plan.
In a letter to the "News" last week, Mr.
Richard H. Pleasants, of the Baltimore bar,
made the suggestion that the city should
purchase the present buildings of the University for the use of its various free schools.
He gave several reasons for thinking that
such an action would be desirable, among
which were the following:
It would give the University the nucleus
of a fund for the erection of new buildings
on our grounds at IIomewood.
It would provide homes for the Polytechnic Institute, the Maryland Institute and a
finely located public hall for educational
gatherings.
Mr. Keyser, President of the Board of
Trustees of the University, said when told of
Mr. Pleasant's suggestion, that the University was not trying to sell its buildings at
the present time, but that if the city should
renew the offer at any future time when the
University was about to move to Homewood,
it would certainly be favorably considered.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
The group of buildings would naturally be
best adapted for educational purposes and
would be what is needed for the use of the
Maryland and of the Polytechnic Institutes.
President Remsen confirmed what Mr.
Keyser said on the subject, and there seems
to be little chance that the subject will come
up again until the University is moving to
the country, when such a disposition of the
buildings would probably be advantageous
to both sides. The sale of the six buildings
should bring the University quite a large
amount, which would probably come in very
useful for the erection of new buildings at
Homewood.
To the NEWS-LETTER:
Not for a number of years has such lively
interest been evidenced at Hopkins as is
today in athletic sports. There is a general
feeling among the students that Hopkins
must be represented not only on the lacrosse
field, but on the gridiron, the oval and the
diamond, too. When the football team was
recognized a few weeks ago it was a step in
the right direction; but it was only brought
about by the students insisting that the members of the Athletic Board, as their representative, take this action. These same men
are DOW clamoring for a baseball team, saying that if the "prep" schools and small
colleges can be represented by teams playing
the national game, what, then, is the matter
with Hopkins? This early in the year we
are told, and by men who ,know, that there
are over 25 men, the majority of whom
have been stars in other University teams,
and who are ready and anxious to represent
Hopkins on the diamond next Spring. These
men have pledged themselves to play, the
students want a team, and the Ahtletic Association, as the representative body of the
students, should act promptly. If the Athletic Association carries out the will of the
student body, the University will have a
baseball team next Spring.

HOPKINS, 0; U. M., 0.
Backed by about twenty-five or thirty enthusiastic rooters, the 'Varsity foottball team
went to Westminster, Saturday, October 29,
and played a peculiarly interesting game
with Western Maryland College. Despite
the rocky and undulating cornfield on which
the game was played, and which bore no
trace of ever having been marked off, our
men put up a creditable showing. The team
arrived at Westminster about noon, and at
2.30 started down the half-mile cow-path,
which led from the dressing room to the
field. Western Maryland won the kick-off,
and sent the pigskin through a number of
erratic evolutions for the distance of about
ten feet. Hopkins fumbled on the catch and
the ball went to Western Maryland for the
first down. Hopkins held them for downs
and recovered the ball.
About this time the much talked of Roberts, Western Maryland's fullback, received
the greater part of Blanck's knee in the
regions of his dinner. The Western
Maryland rooters began to grow restless and despite the noble efforts of their
leader (whose voice, by the way, was only
harmonious when quiet), their songs lapsed
into a nursery whine of dissatisfaction. This
whine increased as the game proceeded. It
was almost impossible for the referee to
judge downs on the unmarked field. Consequently it was necessary for the line-keepers
to carry the line across the field at every
down, to satisfy our opponents that they
were not being cheated. At the Western
Maryland fifteen-yard line, Blanck, who was
taking the ball around left-end for a touchdown, severely wrenched his ankle on one of
the many small bowlders which were inter-

spersed with the corn stubble, and in falling
he lost the ball. By a series of clever plays
Western Maryland worked the ball up to
Hopkins five-yard line, when time was called.
Hopkins had the kick-off in the second
half, and were about to line up, when there
arose a difficulty which taxed the combined
mathematical abilities of umpire and referee
to settle. The faint line, which before the
game fixed the centre of the field, had faded
into the "heterogeneity" of the ground. The
only other line on the field was behind our
goal posts and it was evidently the intention
of the Western Maryland people that the
kick-off should be from that point, when a
compromise was arranged. It was found
that, with a few irregularities the field sloped
from either end, down to a miniature gorge.
This gorge was decided upon for the kickoff, and Randall sent the ball to what would
have been Western Maryland's I5-yard line.
Hopkins held them for two downs, and end
play was tried by Western Maryland. This
succeeded to the point of losing the ball.
McDonald fell on it, and in the frenzy of
their grief, Western Maryland said they
"wouldn't play unless the ball was returned." As McDonald has scruples about
the humoring of spoiled children, he refused
to comply and was sustained by the decision
of the referee. Western Maryland carried
out their threat and left the field. As the
ball was still in play our men carried it up
for a touchdown. At this point ,one of the
Western Maryalnd backs came out on the
field and wanted to fight Blanek. The latter
was accommodating and the half-back woke
up some ten feet away. The field then
swarmed with the rooters of both teams and
for a few moments things were lively. The

Y. M. C. A. MAIL.
Oh, it's every day I wander,
To the basement down below,
Where the pigeon holes are many
In the J. H. U. P. 0.;
Oh, it's every day I wander,
But forever and for aye,
Come my only, only letters,
From the Y. (why?) M. C. A.
Many cordial invitations,
Do these kindly missives bear.
Such as "Come and be a member,
Join with us in evening prayer;"
Or "A Bible class is forming
Under Mr. So and So,
You'll perform an act of kindness,
If you would but try and go."
And they've other invitations,
Formal bids to formal lunch,
(Tis too bad that at these functions
They debar all Roman punch).
Large receptions in the evening,
"Evening dress is not the style,"
And St. Andrew chapter meetings;
"Just drop in a little while."

Though these bids are very many,
Which I get from day to day,
Four, or five, or six, or seven,
From the Y. (why?) M. C. A.;
Yet another kind of bidding,
Coming first in ones and twos,
Then increasing to the hundreds,
"You will please to pay your dues."
Sometimes think I that these people
Are not financiers a bit,
Spending fortunes out on paper,
Getting nothing back from it.
But of course there are some members,
One, or two, or mayhap, three,
Who do pay with great devotion,
(Oftimes one year out of three).
Surely bills would try a mortal
Much more saintly than am I,
When they teem by tens of hundreds,
While I stand defenseless by;
Think you, I should view them calmly?
Bills are bills, some people say,
True, with but one lone exception,
That's the Y. (why?. M. C. A.
First, I used to like attention
From the Y. (why?) M. C. A.,
Now I do grow tired and tireder,
Tired and more tired every day;
For the way my box is crowded
From the bottom to the top,
Makes me ask the fatal question,
Y. M. C. A won't you stop?
Oh, it's every day I wander,
To the basement down below,
Where the pigeon holes are many
In the J. H. U. P. 0.;
Oh, it's every day I wander,
But forever and for aye,
Come my only, only letters,
From the Y.(why?) M. C. A.

The lady he loved best,
And by her house at evening,
When the sun had gone to rest,
He warbled until daylight
And would have warbled more,
But morning light disclosed a sign
"To Let" upon the door.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
PROGRESS IN THE ORIENTAL
SEMINARY.
The work of the Oriental Seminary has
opened up this year most auspiciously.
About a dozen new students have taken up
work in the Seminary viz., Mr. J. R. Gaar
of Dodson, La., A. B. of Westminster (Texas), College, 1901; Mr. 0. J. H. Preus of Decorah, Ia., A. B. of Luther College, 1901;
Mr. Applestein, Mr. Bernstein, Mr. Bransky,
Mr. Bloudheim, Mr. Potz, Mr. Ellison, Mr.
Edlavitch, Mr. Parelhoff, Mr. Pleet, etc.
The impression is rapidly gaining more
and more ground that ancient history in the
light of the important discoveries made in
Western Asia and Egypt can be treated
authoritatively only by an Orientalist, and
therefore the number of historical students
who avail themselves of Professor Johnston's course on the history of the Ancient
East shows a gratifying increase.
In accordance with its policy of not repeating certain definite courses in rotation
in a cycle of three or four years, as other
departments do, a number of entirely new
courses has been begun in the Oriental Seminary. Professor Haupt interprets this year
the Books of Ruth, Lamentations, and Esther
in the Old Testament Seminary. Professor
Johnston is giving n new course on the
famous Babylonian Code of IIammurabi with
special reference to the corresponding legal
sections of the Old Testament. Dr. Blake,
in addition to his courses in Tagalog, the
principal dialect spoken in the Philippine
Islands, has for the first time begun a course
in Ilokan. Another innovation in the Seminary is Dr. Ember's course in Hebrew conversation, in which the German, Russian and
Polish method of pronunciation is used. As
90 per cent. of Jews at the present time use
this so-called Ashkenazic pronunciation, this
course is important for practical purposes.
Mr. Dennis, who spent last winter with
Dr. Reissner assisting in and directing certain archeological excavations in Egypt, has
returned to the University and will resume
his work in Egyptology under the direction
of Professor Johnston.
Professor Haupt has just published his
new metrical translation of Ecclesiastes.
This translation was read by the author at
the second International Congress for the
History of Religions, held this summer at

11

Basle, and attracted a great deal of attention.
The book is dedicated to President D. C.
Gilman of the Carnegie Institute, whom the
author calls the creator of the First American University.

LOCKE: THE MAN AND HIS WORK.
The programme for the two hundredth
anniversary of the death of the philosopher,
John Locke, which was held in McCoy
Hall, Johns Hopkins University, on Tuesday,
November 1, at 5 P. M., was as follows:
"Locke's Philosophy and Psychology,"
Principal C. Lloyd Morgan of Bristol, England, and Prof. F. J. E. Woodbridge, of
Columbia University.
"Locke as a Physician," Dr. William Osier
of the Johns Hopkins Medical School.
"Locke on Toleration," Prof. J. McBride
Sterrett of George Washington University.
"Locke's Political and Social Views," Dr.
William T. Harris, United States Commissioner of Education.
Professor J. Mark Baldwin, director of the
department of psychology at Johns Hopkins,
will make a brief introductory address as
the presiding officer at the celebration.

MRS. FRANKLIN LECTURES.
Mrs. Christine Ladd Franklin delivered
this week before the Psychological Seminary
of the Johns Hopkins University, her lecture
upon "The New Concept of the Infinite,"
which she recently presented in St. Louis
before the Congress of Arts and Sciences.
The latter part of November Mrs. Franklin
will begin in the department of philosophy
and psychology of the University a course
of lectures in logic and vision. Mrs. Franklin is a fellow of the University.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

NOTES FROM OTHER COLLEGES.
Dr. Dudley Allen Sargent, the well-known
director of Harvard's Hemenway Gymnasium, has just published an authoritative
treatise on Physical Culture under the title
of "Health, Strength and Power."
In this work of 280 pages, Dr. Sargent
has aimed to make physical training more
popular by devising a series of exercises
which require no apparatus whatever. It
is profusely illustrated with half-tone illustrations from original photographs furnished
by the author. At this time, when the benefits of outdoor living and breathing pure
air are being agitated, the simple exercsies,
when followed as here described, cannot but
be found beneficial to the highest degree.
The corporation committee on the retirement of professors has proposed a plan
whereby professors over seventy years of
age who have been with Brown University
twenty yeras or more shall be retired. The
details are not ready for publication, as the
plan must be submitted to the faculty, but
it may be said that the scheme is practically
the same as that in vogue at Yale and other
institutions.
The subject of dress reform is to the fore
at Princeton this year. It has been a fad
with the undergraduate of late years to appear in the class room in the garb of a stone
breaker, and of an impecunious stone breaker at that. Now certain upper-class men
have decided that this habit is injurious to
the reputation of the university and have
undertaken its reform with a fair prospect of
success. Flannel shirts, overalls, brimless
hats have been tabooed and even the sweater
has fallen under the ban.
The latest West Point toast to the ladies
is:
Our arms your defense,
Your arms our recompense—
Fall in!
The rooters in leading eastern universities
are very chary of giving the cheer for individual players on the football field. When

it is given it means something and is one
of the greatest honors that can be accorded
a player. Oftentimes when a man makes
a long gain the one who made the run possible deserves the cheer. Nice discriminations, then, must be made, and when three
cheers are given a man he knows he really
deserved the ovation.
The following are a few of the summaries
of the report of Professor Edwin G. Dexter
of the University of Illinois, who has been
conducting an extensive investigation of injuries received in college football.
1. About one college man in ten the
country over plays football.
2. About twice as large a proportion of
the men in the small colleges play the game
as in the larger universities.
3. About one player in thirty-five is injured sufficiently each season to necessitate
loss of time from college duties.
4. The opinion of college officers regarding the value of the game is about 17 to 1
in its favor.
These results are based on statistics furnished by the officers of sixty of the more
important colleges of the country. The figures cover the last ten years, during which
period of time, out of the number of 22,766
students playing the game 654 were injured
to such a degree that they lost time from
their classes. This is in the proportion of
less than 3 to every 100 players. Of the
serious injuries but eight were of a permanent nature. Three cases resulted fatally;
two of these were untrained men.
President Guy P. Benton, of Miami University, has expressed the following strong
opposition to football:
"I recognise the fact that one college could
not act alone. It would be dubbed a 'sissy'
institution. I should like to see the presidents of all colleges get together to abolish
football.
"I favor athletics, and want boys to have
a good time, but football is too hazardous
to be a justifiable college sport."
Several Miami football players were hurt
in a game at Columbus recently.
